content.rendered:
PROUDLY PRESENTING

MOVING LOAD SIMULATOR

AT QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY

In 2014, Queen’s University’s Civil Engineering Department acquired funding by the Canada Foundation for Innovation (CFI) to produce a machine to support their research of bridge beam design and strength analysis. From their vision of the required machine, a vehicle would roll back and forth along a full-scale bridge beam while applying significant downward loads onto the beam, reproducing the millions of repetitive dynamic loading cycles from the weight of transport trucks.

Dymech Engineering developed that vision into a remarkable and novel machine. The resulting Moving Load Simulator (MLS) is comprised of a vehicle that is pulled along the bridge beam by a 450 hp electric motor, while an on-board hydraulic power unit and actuators can provide downward forces of 56,000 lbs. Within its travel distance of 12.5 m, the vehicle reaches top speeds over 20 km/h and cycle times (end to end) of less than 5 seconds.

The motor drive system is digitally-controlled and features regenerative power technology, which converts the motor into a generator to recover a majority of its power consumption as the vehicle must decelerate to a stop during the second half of every cycle. A custom-designed belt drive system produces the linear motion of the vehicle. The hydraulic load application system is also digitally controlled, with the load on each wheel following a pre-programmed load profile, according to the wheel’s instantaneous location along the concrete beam.

The machine is able to operate continuously and autonomously. A LABVIEW-based operating platform coordinates the two axes of motion and monitors all electronic components for proper functions - including pressure transducers, linear position sensors, absolute encoder, and a suite of safety sensors/switches. In the event of a loss of communication, malfunction, if a measured parameter is outside of predefined limits, or if an emergency stop button is pressed, the system initiates an electrical shutdown.

Within the interface, a test profile builder offers the user a convenient means of quickly producing a testing program, by entering basic motion and load parameters, and selecting from typical load profiles, like sinusoidal and ramped profiles.

From this, the millions of loaded cycles (for fatigue testing compliance) will be be accelerated. Instead of decades of real-life wear-and-tear, the simulator can compress the tests down to several months of continuous and autonomous operation.

The MLS has already provided data collection for one student’s Master’s Thesis project and is currently being reconfigured for a different type of testing for a second graduate student’s Master’s Thesis project. Fundamentally, the machine is expected to be instrumental to this new method for researching the durability of bridge beam reinforcement and structures using dynamic moving load testing. The MLS is the only machine in Canada that can perform moving load testing of full-scale beams, and is the second machine performing this type of testing in North America.

In July 2018, the Faculty hosted a public unveiling and demonstration event, which was attended by approximately 50 people, including prominent representatives of the University, the Mayor of Kingston, the local Member of Parliament, and local news media. Here is a link to the University’s press release from the public unveiling, which highlights the anticipated impact of the machine onto innovative research by these representatives of the University and of the public:

https://engineering.queensu.ca/news-events/moving-load-simulator-unveiled-and-demonstrated/

Special thanks to our partners at Prolucid Technologies Inc. and Drive Centre for their support and contributions to this project.

1736
